column1: The COVID-19 pandemic in the Czech Republic is part of the worldwide pandemic of coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) caused by severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2). The first three confirmed cases in the Czech Republic were reported on 1 March 2020. On 12 March
column2: the government declared a state of emergency
column3: for the first time in the country's modern history for the area of the entire country. On 16 March
column4: the country closed its borders
column5: forbade the entry of foreigners and issued a nationwide curfew. While originally planned until 24 March
column6: the measures were later extended until 1 April and then again until the end of State of Emergency which was extended by the Chamber of Deputies until 30 April 2020 and then again until 17 May 2020.

column1: Some measures undertaken by the Czech Republic differed in key aspects from other countries. A general curfew was in place between 16 March and 24 April
column2: though with numerous exemptions. Apart from the permitting essential shopping and going to and from work
column3: as in other countries
column4: it also permitted visiting relatives and allowed for unrestricted movement in parks and open countryside. A general closure of services and retail sale was in place from 14 March until 11 May; however
column5: all shops could conduct distance sales with delivery through makeshift takeaway windows and gradual opening of selected shops started in several waves from 24 March onwards. Fear
column6: anger and hopelessness were the most frequent traumatic emotional responses in the general public during the first COVID-19 outbreak in the Czech Republic. The four most frequent categories of fear were determined: fear of the negative impact on household finances
column7: fear of the negative impact on the household finances of significant others
column8: fear of the unavailability of health care
column9: and fear of an insufficient food supply. The government didn't order closure of manufacturing plants
column10: but many did so voluntarily during the second half of March with Hyundai spearheading a gradual reopening from 14 April. The Czech Republic was the first European country to make the wearing of face masks mandatory from 19 March onwards. COVID-19 testing was made widely available with drive-through locations from 14 March
column11: and from 27 March anyone with a fever
column12: dry cough or shortness of breath was eligible for a free test. From 13 April onwards
column13: COVID-19 testing capacity significantly surpassed demand. Contact tracing in the country also included voluntary disclosure of mobile phone position and debit card payments data for previous days and the quarantining of identified contacts. By 1 May 2020
column14: altogether 257 COVID-19-related deaths were identified in the Czech Republic compared to 2
column16: which did not impose a full lockdown.

column1: The Czech Republic started gradual easing of measures from 7 April 2020 onwards
column2: with most restrictions being lifted by 11 May 2020.

column1: == Background ==
On 12 January 2020
column2: the World Health Organization (WHO) confirmed that a novel coronavirus was the cause of a respiratory illness in a cluster of people in Wuhan City
column3: Hubei Province
column4: China
column5: which was reported to the WHO on 31 December 2019.The case fatality ratio for COVID-19 has been much lower than SARS of 2003
column6: but the transmission has been significantly greater
column7: with a significant total death toll.

column1: == Timeline January–July 2020 ==
=== 28 January ===
As of 28 January 2020
column2: suspected cases were tested with negative results.

column1: === Week 9 (24 February – 1 March) ===
28 February –
As of 28 February 170 suspected cases were tested with negative results. 307 people were in home quarantine imposed by a regional health authority
column2: 77 of them were in South Bohemian Region.1 March –

column1: The Minister of Health
column2: Adam Vojtěch
column3: reported that three cases of COVID-19 had been confirmed by the National Reference Laboratory. The three cases are treated at the Bulovka Hospital in Prague; one of the cases had been found in Ústí nad Labem
column4: but was transported to the Bulovka Hospital. All cases were connected with northern Italy. One case was a man who returned from a conference in Udine
column5: the second case was a woman (tourist
column6: U.S. citizen) studying in Milan and the third case was a man who returned from a skiing holiday in Auronzo di Cadore.

column1: === Week 10 (2–8 March) ===
2 March –
Another case was confirmed
column2: a woman who was on skiing holiday in Auronzo di Cadore and was staying in the same hotel as the man from a previous case.3 March –

column1: Another case was reported
column2: a woman from Ecuador studying in Milano
column3: a friend of the U.S. tourist who tested positive several days prior. Government started taking active measures (see policies section below).

column1: 5 March –
Four new cases were identified a Czech and an Italian who returned from Italy by the end of February
column2: third was related to case No. 3 and fourth was related to case No. 6.6 March –

column1: Obligatory 14 days' quarantine for people returning from selected parts of Italy announced (see policies section below). As of 6 March 1
column2: 011 people were already in home quarantine imposed by regional health authority
column3: 341 of them in Prague
column4: 160 in South Bohemian Region and 63 in Central Bohemian Region. As of 6 March
column5: some 16
column6: 500 Czechs were in Italy; spring break falls between early February and the middle of March 2020.

column1: 9 March – Bulovka Hospital in Prague has announced that all but two tourists (from U.S. – case No. 2 and from Ecuador – case #5) have been released to home quarantine.10 March –
Positive cases were being identified in ever increasing number of regions.11 March –
Schools closed.12 March –
The Czech government has declared a state of emergency for 30 days and adopted a number of measures (see policies section below).13 March –
Brno University Hospital (a COVID-19 testing center) was hacked
column2: disrupting services.15 March –

column1: Shortly before midnight
column2: Prime Minister Andrej Babiš announced approval of the nationwide quarantine (see policies section below).

column1: 16 March –
Starting at midnight
column2: an hour after the nationwide quarantine declaration was approved the previous day
column3: nearly 11 million Czech residents were placed under quarantine (see policies section below). The Czech Republic became one of the first countries in the EU to completely close its borders (with exemptions including international freight transport
column4: see policies section below). First three people were reported recovered.18 March –

column1: The Czech Republic became the first country in the EU to introduce mandatory face cover (see policies section below).21 March –
Deliveries of protective gear purchased by Czech Government in China started: a heavy cargo plane Antonov An-124 provided through NATO Support and Procurement Agency brought 100 tons of masks
column2: respirators and coronavirus tests from China
column3: while a China Eastern plane brought 7 million face masks. This helped to alleviate the shortage of personal protective equipment (PPE) in the Czech Republic. According to Security Information Service
column4: the shortage happened after Chinese embassy conducted massive purchases of respirators available on Czech market during January and February and transferred them to China.22 March –

column1: First death reported: a 95-year-old man. While COVID-19 positive
column2: at the time of death
column3: the man was not at ICU and did not suffer from pneumonia that is a COVID-19 specific type of death. The man suffered from chronic heart issues and had also a pacemaker. The cause of death was formally established as a "complete exhaustion of organism".

column1: 23 March –

The local health authority in the Moravian-Silesian Region announced that 80% of COVID-19 examinations that were conducted in the region in the previous days with use of fast-test kits that government procured and airlifted from China (altogether 300
column2: 000 kits bought by the Czech Government for total price of CZK 54 m—approximately US$2.1 m) came out wrong when double-checked through standard testing.

column1: It was later confirmed the cause was an incorrect use where the fast-test react to an immune response and are not suitable for new patient screenings.24 March –

A second death was reported: a 45-year-old man died after six days in a hospital in Havířov. The patient was suffering from advanced cancer with metastases to multiple organs. The cause of death was established as multiple organ failure due to cancer but COVID-19 infection accelerated the patient's death.A third death was reported: a 71-year-old woman died in Všeobecná fakultní nemocnice in Prague. The woman suffered from the chronic obstructive pulmonary disease as well as other illnesses
column2: so it wasn't immediately clear that she may be COVID-19 positive. Only after being hospitalised the woman informed doctors that her relative recently returned from Italy and was then tested for COVID-19. The woman was connected to a ventilator but died three days after start of hospitalisation.Apart from the Uber driver on ECMO
column3: there were 19 other patients in hospitals in serious condition
column4: all of them connected to ventilators.25 March –

column1: The fourth and fifth deaths were reported: The fourth victim of the disease is an 82-year-old from Prague with long-term chronic health problems. The fifth patient is an 88-year-old man from the Central Bohemian Region who was at home getting treatment and was suffering from a chronic disease.A sixth patient died at Thomayer Hospital. The 75-year-old patient suffered from diabetes and Parkinson's disease and also had advanced heart problems. The patient had been in the hospital since January and got infected while in post-operative care. After this patient tested positive for COVID-19
column2: the hospital tested all 29 other patients in the same ward on 22 March
column3: all negative. The test was repeated again on 25 March
column4: this time with positive outcomes for 13 patients. Several of the hospital's staff had become infected earlier
column5: probably while taking care of the Uber driver who would later become the first remdesivir receiver in the country. This patient was originally admitted with simple pneumonia without initial indication of COVID-19. Two of the infected nurses were hospitalised at the local pulmonary ward at the time of the sixth patient's death.The government was planning to evacuate Czechs from Australia and New Zealand by the end of the week. Hundreds of Czechs still remained abroad
column6: mainly in Oceania and Southeast Asia.An Antonov An-124 provided through the NATO Support and Procurement Agency arrived again with 24 tons of medical products purchased by the Czech government in China. The shipment included 52
column12: 1.16 million respirators and eight million masks. Further government purchased personal protection equipment shipments were planned for delivery with use of planes by the companies Smartwings and China Eastern
column13: which were contracted for nine flights per week for six weeks in advance.

column1: 26 March –
A Taiwanese student in her twenties
column2: who recently returned to Taiwan from the Czech Republic tested positive for coronavirus. She left the Czech Republic after 8 months in the country on 19 March 2020
column3: announced symptoms (fever
column4: diarrhoea) to Taiwanese authorities on 24 March and was diagnosed COVID-19 positive on 26 March 2020. Thirty-four patients were in severe condition.27 March –

column1: Despite having been quarantined already for two weeks
column2: at least six retirement homes were hit by the spread of the COVID-19 virus. Authorities noted also the rising number of COVID-19 positive healthcare workers. As the capacity for COVID-19 testing increased
column3: authorities eased requirements for free testing. Anyone with a fever
column4: dry cough or shortness of breath may be eligible for a free COVID-19 test.29 March –

column1: Five people died. Among the victims was a 45-year-old nurse from Thomayer Hospital
column2: an elderly woman from a senior home in Michle and an elderly woman from a senior home in Břevnice. There were 227 patients in hospitals
column3: 45 of them in severe condition.

column1: === Week 14 (30 March – 5 April) ===
30 March –
In South Moravia
column2: testing of the so-called "smart quarantine" was started: local travel history of infected persons were to be tracked using data from mobile phones and bank cards. Three hundred military personnel were deployed to reinforce local health authority for the purpose of tracing patients' contacts and collecting samples. If this approach is deemed successful by the authorities for diminishing the pandemic
column3: the "smart quarantine" method is planned to replace the existing nationwide curfew policy. The city of Uherský Brod started thorough disinfection of all common areas of apartment buildings and public areas after a significant increase in COVID-19 infections. Health authority registered thirty new cases in the town. The Government also issued a decree for citizens to make cloth face masks for the nation.31 March –

column1: In a community of 72 people living in a retirement home in Litoměřice
column2: 52 positive tests were confirmed.

column1: Employees of the retirement home in Česká Kamenice decided to stay with their clients 24 hours a day until 15 April
column2: to avoid the seniors getting COVID-19.1 April –

column1: One month ago the Czech Republic reported the first coronavirus case. A second senior from the Litoměřice retirement home died
column2: as well as seniors from Prague and Moravia-Silesia. The Department of Infectious Diseases of the Central Military Hospital in Prague has treated COVID-19 patients with hydroxychloroquine. Eight of them have already been released for home quarantine. The evaluation of preliminary results of this therapy will be carried out in April. Chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine were originally used to treat malaria
column3: but at present they also help patients with autoimmune diseases—rheumatoid arthritis or systemic lupus.

column1: The World Health Organization (WHO) considers these substances as one of the options to treat COVID-19.Supreme Administrative Court ruled that Government decision to postpone the Senate district 32 by-election due to COVID-19 pandemic was illegal. According to the court
column2: the Government lacked the authority to make such a decision
column3: as that can only be done by an Act of Parliament. The by-election to fill a seat after Jaroslav Kubera
column4: who died of heart attack
column5: was originally planned on 27 March and would take place on 5 June.

column1: 2 April –

One victim died at the General University Hospital in Prague (VFN); another victim was a 79-year-old patient hospitalised at the Hradec Králové University Hospital. The government decided to extend the border control by 20 days. Border checks with Germany and Austria will last until midnight Friday
column2: 24 April.3 April –

column1: A public controversy has arisen around shipments of personal protective equipment that the Czech Government purchased and airlifted from China. On 31 March
column2: Mayor of Prague Zdeněk Hřib publicly praised Government of Taiwan for donating ICU ventilators to the Czech Republic
column3: while pointing out that all of the equipment from China was purchased
column4: none was donated. Representatives of China's business interest in the Czech Republic countered by claiming that China donated personal protective equipment that was to be handed over to Czech hospitals on 1 April. According to the media
column5: Czech authorities received a promise of donation of PPE; however
column6: none have reached the country by 3 April 2020.4 April – There were 29 infected police officers in the Czech Republic

column1: 6 April – Government eased a number of restrictive measures
column2: e.g. by opening outside sporting grounds (including skiing
column3: shooting ranges
column4: etc.)
column5: movement in parks and nature without face masks and opening of more shops and services (see policies section below).

column1: 7 April – Government sought extension of the State of Emergency for 30 days
column2: i.e. until 12 May 2020. Chamber of Deputies of Parliament granted extension until 30 April 2020.12 April – Government announced that it was preparing a plan for gradual lifting of remaining restrictions. Government aimed at reaching maximum of 400 newly infected people a day in order to prevent overburdening the healthcare system. Instead of general restrictions
column3: the intended maximum number should be reached through contact tracing of positive cases (see policies section below).

column2: 000 a day to mere 3

column4: testing capacity during Easter weekend significantly surpassed demand for testing from potential patients. Health authority expected the demand to rise again in the following week.14 April – A month-long complete border closure ended (see policies section below). A large number of Czech Romanis started returning from particularly hit United Kingdom

column11: many had decided to close voluntarily.

column1: The Czech government outlines a five-step plan for re-opening shops

column5: without spectators
column6: Weddings of up to 10 people following hygiene rules

column2: except for those in shopping centers over 5

column2: shops over 1

column4: indoor areas of restaurants
column5: cafes
column6: pubs
column9: hotels and other accommodation providers (and their restaurants and cafes)
column14: chateaux and other cultural activities according to the current regulations
column15: mass events for a specified number of people
column18: and sports events for less than 50 people

column21: with most being lifted by 11 May.

column1: 22 April – Prime Minister Andrej Babiš announced that the Government will not request the Chamber of Deputies of the Parliament to extend the State of Emergency beyond 30 April. Meanwhile
column2: Minister of Interior announced that he will seek further discussion of the topic
column3: claiming that State of Emergency is crucial for Government's ability to fast procure and distribute personal protection equipment outside of standard lawful procurement process.

column1: The court determined that the fact that measures were not adopted by the Government under the Crisis Act powers
column2: but by Ministry of Health under the Protection of Public Health Act
column3: leads to violation of constitutional guarantees of separation of powers. When adopting measures under the Crisis Act
column4: the Government is continually under the supervision of the Chamber of Deputies of Parliament. Under Art 5(4) of the Constitutional Act on the Security of the Czech Republic
column5: the Chamber of Deputies can revoke the State of Emergency at any moment. Thus taking away Government's power to adopt crisis measures under the Crisis Act
column6: including those that violate basic rights. Adoption of the measures by Ministry of Health under the Act on Protection of Public Health frustrated this control by the Chamber of Deputies. In effect
column7: the respondent impermissibly restricted constitutional powers of the Chamber of Deputies.

column1: 23 April – The Municipal Court in Prague invalidated some of the restrictions adopted in order to battle the COVID-19 spread. In particular
column2: the court invalidated Ministry of Health Protection Measures that introduced curfew
column3: banned hospital visits and banned selected retail sale and services. The court held that such wide restrictions of basic rights may be adopted only under the Crisis Act by the Government as whole and not under Protection of Public Health Act by the Ministry of Health alone. Both the curfew and retail sale ban were originally adopted by Government Resolutions on 14 and 15 March
column4: respectively; however
column5: then they were replaced by Ministry of Health Protection Measures from 24 March onwards. The court invalidated these measures from 27 April onwards
column6: giving the Government three days to remedy the situation. The Ministry of Health may lodge an appeal to the Supreme Administrative Court. On the day of court's decision
column7: there were suits against 17 other measures still pending.While Ministry of Health Protection Measures may be adopted indefinitely
column8: Government Measures under Crisis Act may be adopted only for period of State of Emergency. Government may declare State of Emergency for period of 30 days
column9: any prolongation requires assent of the Chamber of Deputies.24 April – In line with the decision of the Municipal Court of Prague
column10: the Government announced that it would seek Chamber of Deputies' consent to extend the State of Emergency until 25 May. At the same time the Government announced a faster roadmap for the lifting of restrictions.

column1: === Week 18 (27 April – 3 May) ===
28 April – The Government sought an extension of the State of Emergency until 25 May 2020. The Chamber of Deputies of Parliament granted an extension until 17 May 2020.
6 May – The Ministry of Health presented the outcome of the COVID-19 prevalence study conducted over the previous weeks. Out of 26
column2: 549 people (volunteers and vulnerable groups with chronic diseases) tested for the presence of anti-bodies
column3: the countrywide testing identified only 107 people with antibodies who were previously undetected. This showed a high success rate of contact tracing and quarantine measures and a very low rate of virus presence in the general population.

column1: State of Emergency ended on 17 May. Extraordinary measures either ended or were extended beyond the State of Emergency with lesser restrictions. According to Ministry of Health
column2: the main aim going forward was to achieve three main objectives:

column1: Prevent hospital overcapacity in order to be able to provide necessary care to all patients with COVID-19
column2: including non-hospitalised. The main aim is to preserve Czech COVID-19 mortality at 2–3% as before and to prevent it's rise to worldwide average of 7% or French mortality of 18%.

column1: Prevent "explosive spread" of COVID-19 that would (a) include spread of more aggressive types of COVID-19 or (b) higher concentration of COVID-19 in body
column2: as those lead to more dangerous development of illness.

column1: Further lower mortality as better knowledge about COVID-19 and use of promising experimental drugs like remdesivir and hydroxychloroquine becomes available.A court ordered pre-trial detention of a first person charged with spreading of COVID-19. A 32-year-old woman was arrested for movement at a public space without a face mask
column2: although she had been personally ordered to remain in quarantine. Despite quarantine order
column3: the woman used a taxi and visited a shopping mall. The woman was jailed at a hospital ward of Brno prison. If convicted
column4: she may be sentenced to up to 8 years' imprisonment.

column1: A new major COVID-19 hotspot emerged in the city of Karviná. Over 150 workers became infected at a black coal mine where miners work in tight shafts as deep as 1
column2: 000 metres underground. Authorities expected the number to significantly rise further as the workers' family members were likely to become positive later. Among those infected were also many foreign workers from Poland
column3: where coal mines became hotspots in previous weeks. Health authority planned to conduct testing of all 2
column4: 400 workers within three days. Czech Army deployed six medical teams to assist local authority in collection of samples and contact tracing. As of 22 May
column5: up to 40% of infected miners had no symptoms with many others reporting tiredness as the only symptom. Meanwhile
column6: a school was temporarily closed down in nearby city of Havířov after a child of one of the miners tested positive. Apart from the coal mining hotspot
column7: authorities deemed situation in the rest of the country as stable
column8: except for Prague where they identified several small clusters with community spread.

column1: === Week 23 (1–8 June): Further lifting of restrictions
column2: opening of borders ===

column1: Most restrictions have been lifted. Borders were reopened and events of up to 500 people allowed.
=== Week 27 (27 Jun – 5 Jul) ===
1 July – OKD suspends mining in Karviná area following COVID-19 outbreaks. In the ČSM mines
column2: 704 of the 3
column3: 403 employees tested were positive for COVID-19. That equates to 20.7 percent
column4: but the vast majority of them had no or only very mild symptoms of the disease.

column1: 23 July – An outbreak of coronavirus linked to a music club in Prague has increased to 98 cases
column2: including footballers from several of the city's clubs. Czech Republic reported 247 new cases on Wednesday
column3: the highest number since a spike in late June in Karvina.In order to combat an uptick in coronavirus cases in the country
column4: Institute of Health Information and Statistics presented the Czech regional traffic light rating system
column5: which has four levels.

column1: == Timeline August–December 2020 ==
27 August – UK removes Czech Republic from list of "green" countries. Travelers arriving from the Czech Republic will have to quarantine from 4 am on Saturday
column2: the UK government has announced.The Czech PM Andrej Babiš nixes the preventive face mask regulations established by Health Ministry
column3: which were supposed to come in place when the school holidays are over the 1st of September. Masks will now not be needed anywhere in schools
column4: with the exception of schools that make it to the “orange” level of medium-risk for COVID-19 in the Czech Republic's regional health map.

column1: Public transportation vehicles
column2: health facilities
column3: and voting stations will require masks.

1 September – 257 new cases reported. Mandatory to wear face masks on public transport
column2: public indoor areas (such as shopping malls
column3: offices
column4: post offices
column5: offices) and indoor public events
column6: regardless of the number of visitors.

column1: Schools are excluded from the restrictions.Schools re-open across the country
10 September – 1
column2: 161 new cases. Number of new cases has now exceeded 1
column3: 000 for the past two days.

column1: face masks will be required in all indoor spaces throughout the Czech Republic from today.
There are a total of 25 exceptions to that requirement

column1: 18 September – The Czech Republic reported more than 3

Roman Prymula will become new Czech Health Minister.
Prymula predicted that the daily number of COVID-19 cases in Czech Republic will soon reach 6

column1: Dušek also stated that from the beginning of the epidemic until mid-September

column1: 5 October – The Czech Republic comes under a state of emergency. Indoor events with over 10 participants will be prohibited
column2: the same applies to outdoor events with over 20 participants.

column1: Professional sport matches will be without spectators and can be attended by a maximum of 130 athletes

column3: and other members of the staff.

column1: Limit of 30 people for weddings and funerals
Restrictions will also apply to the number of people sharing one table at restaurants and other catering facilities as only six people at most will be allowed to sit at one table.
Educational facilities would follow the instructions of their regional public health authorities

column1: A restriction on tuition in the form of a switch to distance learning is to apply to secondary and higher vocational schools and universities in regions with a red or amber.
Kindergartens and first stage primary schools remain regularly open

column1: The wearing of face masks is mandatory in all interior spaces of universities.
No restrictions on traveling were introduced8 October – New record with 5
column2: 335 new COVID-19 cases reported in the Czech Republic. The Czech Republic overtook Spain as Europe's most-affected country.

column1: The percentage of COVID-19 patients requiring hospitalization rose above 4% for the first time in three months.
Secondary schools and universities have switched to distance learning but only in high-risk areas of the Czech Republic.
Visits and tours to zoos and all organized hobby

column1: Kindergartens and primary schools remain regularly open
column2: where no face masks will be needed.9 October – The Czech government announced new restrictions. Indoor sports facilities and culture venues will have to close for 2 weeks. Restaurants and other catering facilities will have to close as early as 8 pm. Dining establishments will be limited to 4 people at one table
column3: and pupils in the upper level of elementary schools will alternate in-class and distance learning.

Lower levels of elementary schools

column1: 12 October – The presence of students at universities will be prohibited
column2: with the exception of clinical and practical teaching aa well internships in study programmes for general medicine
column3: dentistry
column4: pharmacology and other healthcare study programmes. Measures were also taken on 12 October that were intended for elementary and secondary schools
column5: but they were substantially changed the following day.

column1: 13 October – Czech government unveiled very strict anti-COVID measures. They will be valid for 14 days
column2: starting from the 14th of October. The new measures include the closure of pubs and restaurants and a ban on public alcohol consumption. Pubs and restaurants may still operate on a delivery and takeaway basis. Takeaway windows can only operate until 8 p.m. Additional measures are aimed at preventing people from gathering in public. They include a limit on group sizes to a maximum of six people. The requirement to wear a face mask in all train
column3: tram
column4: and bus stations is mandatory. All primary and secondary schools will switch to distance learning. The measures regarding schools will last through 1 November. Playgrounds and kindergartens remain open without any restrictions.Police from the 11th General Crime Department of the First Police District in Prague uncovered an underground venue on Vodičková Street in central Prague operating after 8 p.m.
column5: with around 35 guests packed into a cellar bar
column6: who were drinking
column8: and consuming drugs in late hours of the night.15 October – A record 9
column9: 500 COVID cases out of a record amount of 30

column1: Czech Railways restricts connections and will adjust the operation of long-distance trains beyond rush hours.
Prime Minister Andrej Babiš announced the government will start increasing the number of beds outside hospitals this weekend. Around 3
column2: 000 beds plus an additional 1
column3: 000 for specialized treatment. Locations the government is looking at are spa facilities around the country and a field hospital
column4: to be built by the army
column5: at the Letňany Exhibition Center.18 October – A Sunday-afternoon demonstration against the Czech government's anti-coronavirus restrictions ended in dramatic clashes between protesters and the police after the rally was officially terminated. There were roughly 2
